contentfulBlogPost.title: To Understand the US Pandemic, We Need Hospitalization Data—and We Almost Have It

childMarkdownRemark.html: Whet Moser is a freelance writer in Chicago.
Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.

description.description: The COVID Tracking Project collects and publishes the most complete testing data available for US states and territories.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jonathan Gilmour is a Data Infrastructure engineer and Data Quality contributor at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: 20,000 Hours of Data Entry: Why We Didn’t Automate Our Data Collection

lede.lede: Looking back on a year of collecting COVID-19 data, here’s a summary of the tools we automated to make our data entry smoother and why we ultimately relied on manual data collection.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: A Wrap-Up: The Five Major Metrics of COVID-19 Data

lede.lede: As The COVID Tracking Project comes to a close, here’s a summary of how states reported data on the five major COVID-19 metrics we tracked—tests, cases, deaths, hospitalizations, and recoveries—and how reporting complexities shaped the data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: How Lagging Death Counts Muddled Our View of the COVID-19 Pandemic

lede.lede: During the worst parts of the COVID-19 pandemic, the United States struggled to keep up with COVID-19 death counts.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Releasing Our State COVID-19 Data Log

lede.lede: From July 2020 to March 2021, The COVID Tracking Project compiled a detailed set of structured COVID-19 data notes, both on changes states made to the data and changes we made to the data we captured from states. Today, we’re releasing those notes.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How We Entered COVID-19 Testing and Outcomes Data Every Day for a Year

lede.lede: We set up a set of roles and a shift system to carefully gather and inspect the data we published.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: Inconsistent Reporting Practices Hampered Our Ability to Analyze COVID-19 Data. Here Are Three Common Problems We Identified.

lede.lede: With little consistency in how states defined, published, and presented COVID-19 data, it is difficult to compare situations across states.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.

blog_post.title: Releasing Our Annotations on State COVID-19 Current Hospitalizations Data

lede.lede: As part of our wind-down process, we are releasing a one-time snapshot of our research into states’ current hospitalization definitions.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: A New Surge Has Arrived in Michigan, but We Don’t Know What It Will Look Like

lede.lede: According to federal data, COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations have reversed their decline in Michigan, marking a new surge concentrated in and around Detroit, but affecting regions statewide.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Releasing our Annotations on COVID-19 State Data Definitions

lede.lede: As part of our wind-down process, we’re publicly sharing our structured metadata on state COVID-19 data definitions.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: What We've Learned About the HHS’s Hospitalization Data

lede.lede: Despite a rocky beginning, the current hospitalization and new admissions metrics from the HHS Protect public dataset have stabilized—and they’re now largely harmonious with state-reported hospitalization metrics if we account for differences in data definitions and reporting lag time.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Where to Find Simple COVID-19 Data for the US

lede.lede: As The COVID Tracking Project approaches its final day of data compilation on March 7, 2021, we are recommending a selection of federal data sources to people who want a quick and easy way to keep an eye on the pandemic.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Joseph Bensimon is a member of the COVID Tracking Project’s Data Quality team.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Death Numbers

lede.lede: The CDC provides two different datasets regarding COVID-19 fatalities. Here’s a walkthrough of how they compare to each other and to The COVID Tracking Project’s data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How Day-of-Week Effects Impact COVID-19 Data

lede.lede: An understanding of state reporting schedules and day-of-week effects can help explain the reasons that numbers fluctuate from day to day, and what those changes mean.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Nicki Camberg is a student journalist studying Political Science and Statistics at Barnard College, and the City Data Manager at CTP.
Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Kara Oehler is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Judith Oppenheim works on Texas City Data and state outreach at The COVID Tracking Project.

Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.
Aarushi Sahejpal is a Shift Lead on Long-Term Care and City Data at the COVID Tracking Project. She also studies International Relations & Data Science at American University

Sharon Wang is a volunteer on the COVID Tracking Project and has supported data collection, process design and other various needs. Sharon is also the CEO and Founder of Pragmatic Strategy Co, a boutique consulting firm helping organizations create longevity in their business through operational and leadership effectiveness.

blog_post.title: Introducing the COVID Tracking Project City Dataset

lede.lede: Our new data collection tracks the spread of COVID-19 in 65 cities and counties across the United States, and it lets us see how fatality rates vary widely across geographies.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Amanda French, Community Lead and Data Entry Shift Lead at The COVID Tracking Project, has a doctorate in English and is an expert in digital humanities.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

blog_post.title: The “Good” Metric Is Pretty Bad: Why It’s Hard to Count the People Who Have Recovered from COVID-19

lede.lede: We don’t know how many people in the US have really recovered from COVID-19.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Visualizing COVID-19’s Impact on Hospitals Across the Country

lede.lede: The HHS released a facility-level data set on COVID-19 hospitalizations in December. We’ve taken that data and created an interactive map, allowing the public to see how their local hospitals are faring against this virus.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: All Eyes on Hospitalizations: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 30

lede.lede: Holiday reporting has garbled most metrics. Going by current COVID-19 hospitalizations, outbreaks in the Midwest are still easing, but every other region is in trouble.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How We Source Our Data and Why It Matters

lede.lede: States provide COVID-19 data in a variety of sources and formats. To ensure our data is as accurate and consistent as possible, we spend a lot of time looking at these sources to make sure that we’re capturing the most data possible for each state, while maintaining high standards of data quality and integrity. Today, we’re publicly releasing a detailed set of notes on the sources of all our data points.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Current, New, and Cumulative Hospitalizations: What They Are and Why They Matter

lede.lede: COVID-19 hospitalizations continue to rise across the country, but the method in which they are reported can take several different forms. We dive into the meaning of some of the most common metrics and comment on why some may be more interpretable than others.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.
Betsy Ladyzhets is a Research Editor at Stacker and works on data quality and the COVID Racial Data Tracker at the COVID Tracking Project.

Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.

blog_post.title: New HHS dataset tells us precisely where COVID-19 is hitting hospitals

lede.lede: The Department of Health and Human Services released a new public dataset on December 7 that includes data down to the facility level on where COVID-19 patients are hospitalized and how healthcare systems are coping. We explored how to use this dataset and what patterns it can reveal.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Cases Matter

lede.lede: As COVID-19 cases rise across the United States, claims are circulating that case increases are (mostly or entirely) due to expanded testing, and do not indicate a spike in infections. The data does not support this conclusion.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.
Joseph Bensimon is a member of the COVID Tracking Project’s Data Quality team.

blog_post.title: As North Dakota’s Deaths Metrics Diverge, We’re Switching to a Less Backlogged Measure of Fatalities

lede.lede: North Dakota's growing backlog of death certificates means its count of individuals who died due to COVID is no longer an accurate measure of deaths in the state. As a result, we're switching our metric to deaths among cases, matching the state’s most prominent method of reporting.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Daily COVID-19 Data Is About to Get Weird

lede.lede: The upcoming holiday means that many COVID-19 metrics are going to drop—and then rise—in ways that may trip up unsuspecting observers. Here’s what to watch out for.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: COVID-19 Hospitalizations Have Hit an All-Time High

lede.lede: More people are now in the hospital with COVID-19 than ever before, and the per-capita hospitalization rates in the Midwest have now surpassed those of the South in the summer’s Sunbelt surge. Hospitals across the country are warning of staff and PPE shortages, and case rates continue to spike in every US region.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: COVID-19 Deaths Are Rising, But Fatality Rates Have Improved

lede.lede: As COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations once again rise across the United States so, inevitably, will deaths. But there is reason to hope that we will not see the devastating fatality rates of the initial spring surge.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.
Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Confirmed and Probable COVID-19 Deaths, Counted Two Ways

lede.lede: We're up to 24 states publishing both confirmed and probable COVID-19 deaths, and we're adding those data points into our API. But states are also using two different ways of deciding which deaths to count as COVID-19 deaths.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Is There a Right Way to Chart COVID-19 Deaths Over Time?

lede.lede: States across the US use two primary methods for announcing COVID-19 deaths: date of death (reported) and date of death (actual). To analyze how the pandemic is trending across the country, understanding the relationship between these two data points is crucial. Here's what we've learned from investigating both methods in three of our largest hotspots: Arizona, Florida, and Texas.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: Why The COVID Tracking Project’s Death Count Hasn’t Hit 200,000

lede.lede: Several sites tracking the progression of the virus hit a grim milestone today: more than 200,000 deaths since the pandemic began. Our figures haven’t yet reached that level. Here’s why.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Testing In Limbo, Hospitalizations and Deaths Still Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 10

lede.lede: A long holiday weekend makes ambiguous testing data even harder to understand, but hospitalizations are dropping, which is good.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Joanna Pearlstein is an editorial lead at the Covid Tracking Project and a former editor at WIRED and Protocol.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Holiday Reporting Lags Interrupt Positive Trends: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 17

lede.lede: Though cases are rising in parts of the Midwest, hospitalizations in the West and South continued trending downward. The Labor Day holiday impacted data reporting lag times both this week and last, obscuring what had been positive trends in September.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Finally, Some Good News. This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 20

lede.lede: Key data points in our COVID-19 tracking are finally beginning to trend positively. In the South, tests rose while cases fell, a pattern not seen there since early spring. Hospitalizations fell for the third week straight, but deaths remained above 1,000 a day on average.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.
Betsy Ladyzhets is a Research Editor at Stacker and works on data quality and the COVID Racial Data Tracker at the COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Hospitalization Data Reported by the HHS vs. the States: Jumps, Drops, and Other Unexplained Phenomena

lede.lede: In mid-July the federal government began requiring hospitals to report COVID-19 data to the HHS rather than to the CDC. We compared current hospitalization data reported by the federal government and state health departments since the switch, and found contradictions that suggest the federal data continue to be unreliable, while the state datasets face their own challenges.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Robinson Meyer is a co-founder of The COVID Tracking Project and a staff writer at The Atlantic.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: What’s Going on with COVID-19 Hospitalization Data?

lede.lede: Data for current COVID-19 hospitalizations in the United States—one of our most valuable metrics for understanding the pandemic and its effects—has become highly erratic in recent weeks. Here's what we've learned from watching the data closely, and from our initial analysis of the hospitalization data being published by the federal government.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Alice Goldfarb leads The COVID Tracking Project’s part in The COVID Racial Data Tracker, and is a Nieman Visiting Fellow.

blog_post.title: Record New Cases, Surging Hospitalizations, Rising Deaths: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 9

lede.lede: The South continues to be the epicenter of surges in both cases and hospitalizations. In Arizona, Florida, South Carolina, and Texas, COVID-19 deaths have begun to climb following jumps in new cases. And for the first time since April, deaths are rising nationally.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Whet Moser is a freelance writer in Chicago.
Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.

blog_post.title: To Understand the US Pandemic, We Need Hospitalization Data—and We Almost Have It

lede.lede: Hospitalization data can help us understand the severity of COVID-19 outbreaks in the United States, and even see a little bit of what's to come. Until very recently, we didn't have a national summary figure—now we can finally piece together a national statistic from states that provide it, and estimate the rest.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Whet Moser is a freelance writer in Chicago.

blog_post.title: Why Changing COVID-19 Demographics in the US Make Death Trends Harder to Understand

lede.lede: COVID-19 death data lags behind testing data in ways we mostly understand. What we only partly understand is how an infection rate that seems to be skewing younger will affect the death toll in surging regional outbreaks.

That’s the news from Milan, ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/20477724.2020.1785782"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"where hospital fatality rates fell from 24 percent to 2 percent","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" from March to May (and the percentage of hospitalized patients who needed to be admitted to intensive care units also dropped). ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cebm.net/covid-19/declining-death-rate-from-covid-19-in-hospitals-in-england/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"In England, the hospital fatality rate fell from 6 percent in April to 1.5 percent in June","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Researchers have suggested a variety of reasons for this decline in hospital deaths. The authors of the Milan paper suggested several factors, including a better understanding of the disease’s effects, a reduction in the severity of the local outbreak, and a decline in simultaneous infections with seasonal illnesses. “Patients with COVID-19 in late March and early April included a significant proportion of patients who caught the infection in hospital,” the authors of ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cebm.net/covid-19/declining-death-rate-from-covid-19-in-hospitals-in-england/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"the British Medical Journal report on the decline in hospital mortality rate in England","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" wrote. “These patients, because they were in hospital, were more likely to be sicker and more vulnerable than patients who acquired infection in the community and so more likely to die from COVID-19.” ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"But as the share of patients with infections from community transmission increases, the mortality rate has still declined. Several factors might explain this: ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/blog/why-changing-covid-19-demographics-in-the-us-make-death-trends-harder-to"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Current patients are younger and less likely to die","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", hospitals are admitting less severe cases because more beds are available, and doctors and nurses have learned from experience. Bob Wachter, chair of the University of California-San Francisco Department of Medicine, posted a list of ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://twitter.com/nataliexdean/status/1277929443693146112/photo/1"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"“Things We’ve Gotten Better At Since March”","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"; it includes a number of improvements that could affect in-hospital mortality, such as better monitoring of vital signs and a more effective use of ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2766292"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"prone (face-down) positioning","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", which has been observed to ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.medpagetoday.com/infectiousdisease/covid19/87131"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"improve oxygen levels in severely ill COVID-19 patients","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"\n","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"We still don’t know how the death curve will respond to increasing hospitalizations in the United States.","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" In certain states, the rise in hospitalizations has been very sharp. Between June 2 and July 2 ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/arizona"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"in Arizona","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", the number of people hospitalized with COVID-19 rose from 1009 to 2,938. During the same period ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/california"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"in California","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", COVID-19 hospitalizations rose from 4,393 to 6,812. For the same dates ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/texas"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"In Texas","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", COVID-19 hospitalizations jumped from 1,773 to 7,382. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"RBZaGBkA5MTYSPjBT3Zto","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"(Note: Case fatality rates are a useful metric, but can be biased toward higher death rates, since the most severe cases tend to get tested. This is especially true for fatality rates within hospitals. They should not be translated directly to the overall fatality rate of COVID-19.)","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The patchy history of US COVID-19 hospitalization data ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In the early months of the pandemic, it was impossible to know how many people in the United States were hospitalized with COVID-19. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://twitter.com/covid19tracking/status/1247040773972824064?lang=en"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"On April 5th","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", when we began compiling hospitalization data, only 13 states reported how many people were in the hospital with COVID-19. Twenty-five other states reported the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"cumulative","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" number of people who had been hospitalized. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Current hospitalization numbers","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" go up when COVID-19 patients are admitted or when already admitted patients are diagnosed with COVID-19, and down when COVID-19 patients die or are released from the hospital, or when patients considered to be ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/blog/what-is-a-probable-case-of-covid-19"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"probable cases","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" receive negative confirmatory test results. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Cumulative hospitalization numbers","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" are intended to capture all COVID-19 patients admitted to hospitals, but this number also changes as patients are diagnosed with COVID-19, or when probable cases of COVID-19 are ruled out by negative confirmatory test results.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Because the two hospitalization metrics are fundamentally different kinds of quantities, we could not merge them into a single number that answered the most pressing question: ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"how many people were in the hospital with COVID-19? ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"More than two months from when we started compiling hospitalization data, 47 states, 2 territories, and the District of Columbia now report the number of people currently hospitalized. This has allowed us to create useful national summary statistics about this crucial metric of disease severity. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"One state with worrying case and test positivity trends that doesn’t show up in the hospitalization data is Florida. Its seven-day average for daily new case counts was under 1,000 at the beginning of June; by July 2, the average was over 7,800. Test positivity rose from 5.5 percent in the first week of June to 16.6 percent in the last week. Given those trends, hospitalizations would be expected to climb—but the state hasn’t reported COVID-19–specific hospitalization data except in a single week in May. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Hawaii, Idaho, and Kansas also don’t report how many COVID-19 patients are currently hospitalized, but none are as populous as Florida. While case counts are rising in Idaho and Kansas, the case counts are lower and the rise in new cases is still shallower than in Florida. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"5ugCJ0k15D3bBWXYQ7cTek","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The South Florida ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Sun-Sentinel","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.sun-sentinel.com/coronavirus/fl-ne-coronavirus-hidden-health-data-20200625-fxaqlfnlrbgm3ouzrcm55yhaxe-story.html"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"tracked down hospitalization data","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" from three counties in its region that runs through June 24. As of that date, Miami-Dade County had 981 hospitalized COVID-19 patients, a high since April and up from 787 since June 1. Hospitalizations in Broward County doubled in that timeframe; they were up from 245 to 394 in Palm Beach County. Those are the three largest counties in Florida. In Hillsborough, the fourth-largest, ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.baynews9.com/fl/tampa/news/2020/06/25/hillsborough-health-director--covid-19-cases--hospitalizations-increasing"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"hospitalized patients increased","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" from 196 to 267 from June 18-25 (as positive cases rose 61 percent to over 7,000). In the fifth-largest, Orange County, ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.orlandosentinel.com/coronavirus/os-ne-corovnavirus-record-numbers-hospitalizations-20200626-p5335ddw45f7xdlxiaezqzgjha-story.html"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Orlando Sentinel","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":" reports","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" that 185 patients were hospitalized on June 26. That’s up from 73 on June 15, and a low of 27 on May 10.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Estimating the true extent of COVID-19 hospitalizations in the US","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Because Florida isn’t reporting statewide totals, our regional hospitalization data for the South is considerably lower than the true count. And even without Florida, the trends there are the worst of any US region. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"The chart below shows estimates of the true hospitalization count for each region with non-reporting states included","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"; the trend in the South is the same with and without Florida’s estimate. COVID-19 hospitalizations in the West are also rising, though not as drastically.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"6bsosRIdVm77qXyqzYlW01","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"To derive the estimates in the chart, we take the number of cases reported in a given region over the prior two weeks and calculate the share of those cases that came from states that are not reporting current COVID-19 hospitalizations. We then estimate current hospitalizations for non-reporting states, so that these states have hospitalization estimates proportional to their share of cases. For these states, we assume that the relationship between new cases and hospitalizations is the same as the region as a whole.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"5pDZWtJCCxMys3TRC9xCM2","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"As the chart shows, the national COVID-19 death curve has been closely related to the hospitalization curve until early June. But there’s no reason to think deaths won’t go up again in regions and states where hospitalizations are currently increasing, especially in places where COVID-19 hospitalizations have risen sharply, like ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/arizona"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Arizona","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" and ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/texas"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Texas","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"What remains to be seen is ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"value":"how steeply","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":" death counts will rise.","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" It’s possible the rise in deaths will not be as dramatic, given the changing demographics of the infected, the precedent of Milan and England, and lessons learned about treatment since the beginning of the pandemic. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"But even if a greater percentage of hospitalized COVID-19 patients survive, they could face considerable health problems that we still know very little about.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Note:","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" As of July 2, 47 states and the District of Columbia reported hospitalizations. FL, HI, KS, AS, GU, PR, and MP do not report it. Hospitalization estimates included in the graphics are based on the percentage of all new reported cases over the previous two weeks that occurred in states reporting hospitalization data, compared to those that did not.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

image.title: COVID deaths lag
image.description: Graphic illustrating the ~6 day delay between exposure and onset, the average ~14 day delay between onset and death for those who die of COVID-19, and the ~7 day delay in reporting the death.

image.title: Hospitalizations select states
image.description: Graphic showing trends in hospitalization data for eight states, between June and April.

image.title: Hospitalizations select states 2
image.description: Bar chart showing COVID-19 hospitalizations rising sharply in Arizona, California, and Texas. All data available at https://covidtracking.com/data.

image.title: 20200704 daily positive cases March-July
image.description: Graphic comparing daily positive cases in Florida, Hawaii, Idaho, and Kansas, between March 1 and July 2. Florida's chart spikes significantly higher than the other three states, especially in June and July.

lede.lede: Hospitalization data can help us understand the severity of COVID-19 outbreaks in the United States, and even see a little bit of what's to come. Until very recently, we didn't have a national summary figure—now we can finally piece together a national statistic from states that provide it, and estimate the rest.
